Topic.Title: serious answer only please

Message.Msg: I took a similar position with two sets of spreads, I get crushed at $13, but am ok on the tails above $14 and below $13. I think selling calls at $14 against a long position is almost as close to a "no lose" trade as you can make. Assuming you are holding Dell anyway if the deal blows up and the stock goes back to $11-12 you could keep selling the calls at $13 and that's not a bad way to go.

Topic.Title: If there's an announcement on Monday...then what?

Message.Msg: Monday is only an offer to buy the stock at a specifc price. The shareholders still need to approve the deal. The stock price will move towards the offer price as the details and negotiations take place over the next few weeks. Our decision following the announcement is whether or not to sell or continue to hold to grab more premium and of course simultaneously risk the chance that the deal blows up later.

Message.Title: Something wrong with the math here?
Message.Msg: I've been watching this buyout unfold very closely over the past couple of weeks. With that said, many sources are citing that Microsoft is willing to invest $3 billion into the privatization of DELL. The UK/domestic banks willing to finance the deal have announced $15 billion guaranteed loan. Reuters is reporting a deal around $13-$14. Barrons and Forbes are throwing around $15-$16. Sources are reporting that Microsoft $3 billion dollar stake are going to give Microsoft 10% control of the company. According to NASD, DELL has roughly 1.7 billion shares outstanding. Now if Microsoft receives a 10% stake for $3 billion, doesn't that equal the equivalent of a $30 billion dollar deal in order to go private. Simple math right? $30 billion / 1.7 billion shares = $17.64 share offer on the table? I personally think $17.64 is a tad high per share, however why throw Microsoft 10% of the company for $3 billion? A 10% stake for $2 billion would only be a $20 billion dollar deal or simply $11.76 a share. I think if you take the $17.64 + $11.76 (high/low spectrum), we would probably arrive at the median price of $14.70 for a final price. Many sources are throwing around Microsoft's expected 10% stake, however the numercial amounts are ranging from $2-3 billion investment. Thoughts?

Topic.Title: First deal is not necessarily the final deal

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: In addition if you take the median of Reuters range ($13-14) you arrive at $13.50. If you take the median of Barrons/Forbes ($15-16) then you arrive at $15.50. The median of these numbers equates to $14.50, which is pretty much on par with my $14.70 price expectation mentioned above. I bet it will fall within this range. I guess we'll wait and see. This is what my basic math and math that the news reports are predicting. It cannot be too far off.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: RC, In additional, if you look at the large investment holders (not insiders, but mutual funds), browse their 10K's and filing reports. About 70% of their DELL shares were acquired for less than $13. About 30% of their DELL shares were acquired for more than $13. I did not have time to run the actual prices paid with each firm as that would take a couple days. Some shares were acquired in the early/mid 90's, while many shares were acquired in the past 6/months when DELL was sinking. So if your looking for majority rules, I'm sure the 70% that are in the money would unload their shares between my $14.50-$14.70 range. Heck, this might even pull up another 10% that are in the losing (above $13 paid) either break-even or slightly in the money as well. I'm sure some would undeniably be happy with the $14.50-$14.70 range for break-even or even a slight gain. Why do these metrics matter? Simply said because anywhere from 75-85% shares would vote in favor of the deal. Per NASD us retail folks only control 8% of total DELL shares outstanding therefore we don't exactly have a say/vote in regard to these matters. Let's just hope it works out for everyone where we could all show green in our portfolios. Just my opinion of course.

Apparently, Dell and private equity firm Silver Lake, have been arranging $15 billion in debt financing with the help of Barclays, Bank of America, Merill Lynch, Credit Suisse, and RBC Capital.
Message.Msg: Then early this morning there was the report by Nadia Damouni, Soyoung Kim, and Greg Roumeliotis claiming the company is “edging closer to an agreement to sell itself” for $24 billion, or $13 to $14 per share. Apparently, Dell and private equity firm Silver Lake, have been arranging $15 billion in debt financing with the help of Barclays, Bank of America, Merill Lynch, Credit Suisse, and RBC Capital. Then this afternoon, a Reuters report sans byline stated that “a deal could come as early as Monday,” with Michael Dell taking majority ownership and Silver Lake and Microsoft being minority owners. Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: This is all speculation. But anyways - I don't believe taking reported media averages of pps buyout values is a reasonable strategy though I will acknowledge that they do set up expectations and do have perceived consequences if they aren't met. The key as you allude to, is to provide some comfort for those shareholders who bought high and mitigate lawsuits and bad press. But I am not persuaded in the merit of using those guestimates as a basis - they serve better in spiking interest in share purchaser and in generating expectations of 'fair' valuation among a minority of shareholders (those you ID as having bought above $13). Your valuation based on the MSFT investment is more convincing. I don't think MSFT will throw in $3B because if it is to have a 10% stake, it seems a $30B deal is over-the-top and based on float shares would amount to a pps of almost $20 and I have not heard of any credible estimate that high. I think the most realistic and actuarial basis for starting with an estimate of pps buyout would be to consult the discounted cash flow model reported in the WSJ which results in an implied equity value of 13.60 a share. I think that is the lowest basis and believe any 'fiduciary premium' (FP) would be added to that. In the absence of a FP, the deal will be done for 13.60 per share and there will be considerable threats to litigate the process as well as much bad press - both of which are worth money to avoid. It would be a pretty negative legacy for Michael Dell to cash out shareholders at a pps that reflects the deflating effect of poor management for the last decade. So I do think though that shareholder compensation will likely reflect a 'fiduciary premium' and the question is really how much is that premium and where does the money for it come from? I think M. Dell and insiders who retain their interest in the new private Dell will not be having their shares purchased. After all, they will keep their original shares, and why not? The other equity investors will have shares commensurate with M. Dell's retaining majority control, so his 16% has to somehow become 51%. And I think that 16% is a very interesting number. It might reflect the FP for Dell shareholders. Simple, it is $13.60 + FP of 16% = $15.80. In other posts I also offered alternative back of the envelope methods of 'guestimating' the buyout pps but as of this writing I think $15.80 is my favored estimate, with the most likely range being 15.50-16.50 - allowing the FP to range from 12% - 20%.

Message.Msg: http://online.barrons.com/article/SB50001424052748704843204578245642513078234.html#articleTabs_article%3D1 Think of it. Why would M. Dell who has 16% of shares receive any compensation above a majority stake of the new business? His shares would form the core around which the other equity investors would obtain proportionate interests based on their capital contributions to buy out shareholders. Other small-time insiders of course would be free to sell their shares, but they amount to a pittance compared to M. Dell's and the float.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: You are correct with the $15 per share statement. I'm not disputing your statement, however they could also say they're willing to pay $30/a share. First question is can they afford to $30? Not at all. Could they line up financing to pay $30? Probably not. Could you line up financing for $15/share is the key question. They stated they were green-lighted for $15 billion. Microsoft wants $3 billion, Michael Dell owns 16% of all shares, which equals to $3.55 billion (per closing price on Friday). These three numbers equal $21.55 billion. Minus a billion for Microsoft and let's assume $2 billion, you're looking at $20.55 billion. MSFT's $2-$3 billion has been tossed around, but a more key critical number being tossed around is Microsoft wants that 10% say-so in the new company. Possibly to keep DELL real to their products, possibly to keep their products pre-loaded on DELL's systems. Maybe to use MSFT's office suite instead of DELL jumping to something more open-sourced like Android/Google Office Apps. There's undeniably some motive there and that's surely going to help shareholders in this arranged deal. Question being, aside from the $15 pre-approved financing, $2-3 billion from Microsoft and Michael's $3.55 billion stake. Where's the other money/loans coming from? These three factors only total $20.55 to $21.55 billion (varies depending on MSFT's $2 or $3 billion investment). Granted DELL has roughly $9-$10 billion in hard cash on their balance sheet. Let's assume they borrow a higher credit line against 1/2 ($4.5 to $5 billion) of DELL's cash on hand (then simply pay down the extra loan for the same amount once privatized). DELL would start fresh being a private company with $4.5 to $5 billion in cash. Now's your looking at: Microsoft Investment: $2 or $3 billion Michael DELL's stake: $3.55 billion (could hit $3.75-$4.00 depending on price) Silver Lake Capital: $15 billion loan Silver Lake Capital $5 billion loan (contingent to 1/2 cash balance): $5 billion This would be about $25.55 to $26.55 billion. Divided this by 1.7 billion shares: $25.55 / divided by 1.7b = $15.03 $26.55 / divided by 1.7b = $15.61 I personally don't see them going this route, especially burning through 1/2 their cash (as a retainer if you may) to simply finance the higher price. I'll stick to my $14.50 to $14.70 prediction. Silver Lake would over-extend themselves by existing using cash flows.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: Not trying to sound rude, but if there's a deal Monday, sell at open b/c there's about a 85-90% chance that it will be the best your going to received. Prayer for a competing bid (it's a long shot). Wouldn't be HP as their already drowning from Autonomy. One suitor who likes DELL is Oracle, but Oracle would need immediate plans to spin off the PC division and simply grab the enterprise segment. I don't think Oracle would do such a move right now. Ask again in 18-24/months. Oracle doesn't want another Sun-like situation on their hands (Sun if finalllllly beginning to a benefit to Oracle after years of a being a burden).

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: Glenn - See my post. If Silver Lake pressed to bid $15 a share, they only way they could do it would be as a contingency to borrow half against the $9-$10 billion cash on hand. Then simply repay this once privatizing is completed. See my previous post on this thread. This wouldn't even actually get the share buyout price to $15 ($14.70 tops). It wouldn't make sense for anyone, especially DELL. Dell probably needs about $6-$8 billion to retool and gun for some private/public acquisition to counter moves by HP, Oracle and IBM. I'm a shareholder here, but I do not think we'll even see $15. If we see $15 even, we are truly blessed.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: Savant, I understand what you're referring to however as an FYI remember 70% of all DELL shares held by investment banks/funds were acquired for less than $13. Only 30% of all shares were acquired above $13. It's hard to tell exacts, but what if, and it's simply a what if half of that 30% were bought between $13.01 to $14.99? Throw in Michael Dell's 16% stake and your clearly going to green light a deal at any price really. Most would be undeniably tendered. Retail only owns 8% of all shares. I imagine probably 50-60% of these shares are much higher than $15 per share. The patient longs who bought higher will be the only losers here. It's either do a deal and cash out for slightly more than you had the day/week/month before or watch this falter back to sub-$9, then have someone like Oracle swoop in and pay a measly $12/a share (at which point would be a 25-30% premium. Would you take the lesser premium now or the higher premium later? I'll take a 10% fiduciary premium while we at $13.62 rather than a 30% fiduciary premium when we're trading around $9.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: Good points Euro and I too would take the 13.62 + 10%. That would be a handsome $15 ps from my perspective. And you are right that a bidding war may ensue that could paradoxically produce a lower pps than the original offer. I do think anything less than $15 would draw a red flag and be a costly PR and litigation blunder. Maybe $15 is enough to mitigate that or maybe the principals want to have a larger margin of safety to forestall such criticism? I hope the latter.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: I'm going to stick to my prediction and expectations after crunching the numbers for between 14.50 and 14.70 per share. I have no relation to any talks of any parties involved. I'm simply a finance guy by nature (BBA/MBA/experience). Silver Lake would no way be able to swing a $20 billion credit line without a prior contingency plan in place to tap DELL's cash reserves once it goes private. There goes the special dividend for all you hoping for it. My prediction is $14.50 to $14.70 a share. How do we get there exactly, not quite sure. Could be combination of all-cash deal or even using a portion of DELL's cash as a special dividend. For anyone's guess, we might get $14.50 a share in cash and a or get $13.20 a share in cash and special dividend in the amount of $1.20 (using $2 billion of DELL's cash). This still amounts of $14.50 no matter how many times you clip the scenario. I haven't actually crunched the numbers regarding the cash divided scenario. I personally do not see it as viable. Might happen, might not. It if were to happen, it wouldn't be for more than 20% of DELL's cash.

Topic.Title: Something wrong with the math here?

Message.Msg: Savant, Exactly. They want to do this as quickly and quietly as possible without an ongoing risk of litigation which will slow down the process. Another bidder stepping up to the plate would seriously rock. Then we have the chance to make some nice coin. Just look back at Dell's Quest acquisition, Quest CEO played hardball start-to-finish. 3PAR was also a very nice bidding war. I would pay to see this occur (albeit one problem, we are a little big therefore our suitors are limited). My guess if anyone steps up, it would be Oracle for a fear of what DELL could become (when there's no more public limelight) or simply dismantle the company on their own (selling off the PC and tablet divisions).

Topic.Title: My Basis Disclosure and Estimate

Message.Msg: ae_savant: You are mistaken. Total buyout amount reported in the media, 23.5 Billion, should not be used in the calculation. You must use 20B. Cash raised: Debt 15B Silverlake 2B MSFT 2B Mike Dell (cash only) 1B Total 20B Shares to be compensated 1.46B (dont include Mike Dells shares of 278M) Per share amount that is to be paid to shareholders = 20B / 1.46B = $13.70

Message.Title: Issues
Message.Msg: I appreciate all the 'numbers" indicating what everyone thinks the value is. However, there are other issues: The investment bankers must be convinced that they can make a big return since the risk is so great. A company's worth is what it can return in the future. Keep in mind that this buyout is to effect/cause a change in the direction of the company. That is a huge risk for everyone: the bankers, MSFT, and the Institutions. MSFT is going to a make an investement only if it will have a longterm beneficial effect on MSFT. And what that means is having a say on product developement and marketing, and longterm direction. MSFT is not interested in helping Dell; their only concern is helping MSFT. Do not think they want to be Michaels banker. Steve Balmer is a huge isssue for this deal to work. That is going to be a problem for Michael and Dell's customers.I have a problem understanding how this deal, then partnership, can be equally beneficial to both Dell and MSFT. One of the biggest issues is making sure the Institutional Investors will sell at the offer price. I believe that is what is happen now and is the biggest obsticule. You can bet that before an offer is made some of the biggest Institutions are being courted to be sure they will sell. Dell will not make an offer unless the Institutions are committed. The lawyers are talking 24/7 to see at what price they will commit to sell. I believe that at least one or two or three of the largest Institutions are being asked to stay in, that is, not be a part of the sellers. That allows Michael to become majority shareholder without having to come up with all the cash. That is a big risk. However, that might allow Dell to go private without MSFT, i.e. without Balmer. I do not think this deal will get done unless some of the largest Institutional stay in and I do not see how Michael can do a deal that allows MSFT to be a partner. Comments?

Topic.Title: Issues

Message.Msg: I think mr Ellerbe nailed it. Sell now or hold for the deal is the decision. The deal could close for $2 to $5 more than current PPS or if LBO falls through PPS could drop $2- $3. Is that correct?

Topic.Title: My Basis Disclosure and Estimate

Message.Msg: I'm not actually debating the values, just the calculation. MSFT, Mike Dell and/or Silver lake can come in with more money to raise the price to shareholders. They can also raise more debt or use the cash that's on Dell's balance sheet. My point is that you take whatever cash is being raised and divide by the 1.46B shares that go to all shareholders other than Dell.

Topic.Title: My Basis Disclosure and Estimate

Message.Msg: where is the 14 billion over seas dollars in your calculation- I dont see t hat

Topic.Title: Issues

Message.Msg: Most of your assumptions are wrong. For example, not much risk to banks because they will have Dell's great cash flow business as collateral. Microsoft is lending money, as a bank would , to earn interest or interest-type income on its money. Dell is a significant Microsoft customer, and making what is in effect a financial loan to Dell makes good business sense. "Institutional investor" is a fancy term which usually means nothing more than a retail-type stock buyer. Lots of "insititutional investors" only own a few thousand shares of a given stock. Michael Dell's own share ownership is enough to get whatever he wants approved. he doesn;t need "institutional investor" support.

Topic.Title: Issues

Message.Msg: Bashford: You are too ignorant to reply to but here goes anyway. Microsoft is not interested in interest income. Dell is a customer of MSFT but there are many other customers that Dell has. Are they going to stay happy ( and a customer ) if their competitor ( MSFT ) is calling the shots and knows details about their business? Institutional Investors is not a fancy term for retail investors. Take a look at the top ten Investitional Investors of Dell and you will see who I am referring. The top Institutional Investor has over $1 Billion invested in Dell. Michael Dell cannot do whatever he wants. Without Institutional support nothing is going to happen. If the top five Institutional Investors say they aren't going to sell, then this deal will not happen. You post shows your complete lack of understanding of what is happening.

Topic.Title: $17 to $18 is the whisper number

Message.Msg: its the ONLY way to get a deal done, u dont get it, the "LEAK" is all planned to BRAINWASH you fools then when $18 is offered everyone jumps with joy, get it now???? or do I need to spell it out like u r 3 years old???

Topic.Title: NO DEAL; UNABLE TO AGREE ON TERMS

Message.Msg: The reason it is falling apart is inability to get the debt restructuring done. It is all over wall street. I'm not sure why they are waiting to disclose to the public.

Message.Msg: MrBashfordcapital !! You seem to be promoting a short position on DELL. You may not be all wrong but your argument is not convincing. For instance Balmer lending to Dell for interest income. Doubt it !!!!
